Description:
HIV Prevention and Community Testing Service: 
Lot 1 Black African Communities (BAC) 
Lot 2 Men that have Sex with Men (MSM) 
� 
Background 
� 
Sexual health is an important area of Public Health. Most of the adult 
population of England are sexually active and access to quality sexual health 
services improves the health and wellbeing of both individuals and 
populations. 
� 
Sexual ill health is not equally distributed within the population. STI 
rates including HIV infection in the UK disproportionately affects MSM and 
Black Africans. Some groups at higher risk of poor sexual health face stigma 
and discrimination, which can influence their ability to access services.  
� 
In 2011, 1,062 residents of Leeds received HIV treatment and care. This 
figure is broken down into acquired infection routes as 27% sex between men, 
69% heterosexual with the remaining 4% via intravenous drug use, blood products 
and mother to child transmission routes. 
 
It is estimated that 2.7% of adult males aged 15-49 have genital contact 
with another man in an urban population (CHAPS, 2003:09). When applied 
to the Leeds 15-49 male population this gives an approximate estimate of 5,751 
men engaging in sex with other men in the City. If we look at the full male 
population (15+ 304,200) this gives us a slightly higher estimate of 8,213 as a 
group defined as MSM. 
� 
In Yorkshire and the Humber, 52 per 100,000 people of Black African or 
Caribbean ethnicity are living with the infection in comparison to 4 per 
100,000 people of white ethnicity living with HIV. 
� 
HIV is a long term medical condition and for many is effectively managed via 
treatment. Early diagnosis plays a massive role in both the quality of life for 
the individual and the prevention agenda, heavily reducing the likelihood of 
onward transmission and improving the health outcomes for those testing 
positive. Knowing their status also helps them gain access to further 
knowledge, resources and skills that can help improve their overall health and 
wellbeing.  
� 
Lot 1 Black African communities HIV prevention and community testing 
service 
� 
Scope of this service 
� 
Leeds City Council is seeking to procure a HIV prevention and community 
testing service for Black African Communities (BAC) in Leeds.  
� 
The service is concerned with the provision of services which operate in 
ways to ensure that all Black Africans in the Leeds area; particularly those 
who find it difficult to access information, services and support have targeted 
support around preventing HIV and supporting access to early HIV testing. This 
service will also provide access to information and resources to allow Black 
Africans to make informed choices about their sexual health and general 
wellbeing. The service will also provide HIV community testing sessions and 
will work in partnership with the HIV prevention & community testing 
service provider for MSM and the Integrated Sexual Health Service in relation 
to clinical governance. 
For the purpose of this contract the provider will work in a variety of ways 
to engage with Black African Communities in Leeds including; 
�� Provide HIV prevention and sexual health promotion in locations 
and settings where BAC live and socialise across Leeds.���  
�� Deliver innovative campaigns specific to BAC which increase 
access into sexual health services and promote behaviour change and reduce 
stigma associated with HIV 
�� Deliver weekly community HIV testing targeting BAC 
�� Increase the numbers of BAC accessing HIV/STI testing at the 
Integrated Sexual Health Services 
�� Ensure provision of free condoms and lubricant in Black African 
community settings 
�� Facilitate, enable and promote personal change through 1 to 
1�s, group work and community work 
�� Encourage and empower Black African�s to feel confident and 
comfortable to undertake HIV testing  
�� Support those newly diagnosed to access HIV treatment services 
and Social Care support 
� 
Key service outcomes 
� 
The service will support delivery against the one main sexual health Public 
Health Outcome Framework measures:�  
�� People presenting with HIV at a late stage of infection  
� 
In addition it will deliver the following outcomes to improve sexual health 
of the BAC population in Leeds: 
�� A reduction in the time between infection and diagnosis of HIV 
for BAC 
�� A reduction in the number of undiagnosed HIV infections in BAC 
 
�� A long term reduction in BAC newly acquiring STIs 
�� A reduction in the newly acquired HIV infection rates in 
BAC 
�� A reduction in risk taking behaviours in BAC through a 
self-reported increase in sexual health knowledge, confidence and self-esteem 
and a reduction in risk taking behaviour.  
�� BAC communities in Leeds will be supported to live healthier 
lives  
�

ContractTitle: Integrated Sexual Health Service
Description:
Background 
Leeds City Council is mandated to commission �open access� sexual health 
services. National direction recommends that sexual health services should be 
reconfigured or remodelled to meet the service user�s needs. A series of 
consultations in Leeds has identified clearly what service users now want and 
expect from services.� This will require the integration of sexual health 
services.  
The key feature of integration is that it will provide contraception and 
Human Immunodeficiency Virus / Sexually Transmitted Infections (HIV/STI) 
testing in one visit. This will eliminate the need for multiple services, 
remove duplication and provide an opportunity for the optimum sharing of skills 
and resources. Using this approach will significantly improve the service user 
experience. 
An integrated sexual health service will also lead to better health outcomes 
by reducing unintended conceptions and by reducing the amount of sexually 
transmitted infections in the population. 
Scope of this procurement 
Leeds City Council is seeking to procure an integrated sexual health service 
for Leeds, offering both contraception and Human Immunodeficiency Virus / 
Sexually Transmitted Infections (HIV/STI) testing services. Patients will be 
able to access these services through one, holistic appointment.� The 
service will be open access, confidential and patients will experience rapid 
access to appointments. There will also be a focus on triaging patients to the 
most appropriate level of care. The integrated service will provide a city 
centre hub, plus clinics in areas with the highest rates of poor sexual health 
as indicated in the Leeds Joint Strategic Needs Assessment. The service will be 
delivered in broad accordance with the Level 1, 2 and 3 service model which is 
well established for sexual health service provision. 
The service will provide a leadership role in sexual health within the local 
area and work with all other relevant clinical and non-clinical sexual health 
and healthcare providers to support seamless service provision and health 
promotion. Prevention will be a key priority for the service.  
Key service outcomes 
The service will support delivery against the three main sexual health 
Public Health Outcome Framework measures:�  
 
 Under 18 conceptions 
 Chlamydia diagnoses (15-24 year olds) 
 People presenting with HIV at a late stage of infection 
 
In addition it will deliver the following outcomes to improve sexual health 
in the Leeds population as a whole:  
 
 Improved access to services among those at highest risk of sexual ill 
health 
 Reduced sexual health inequalities amongst young people and young adults 

 Reduced sexual health inequalities amongst BME and MSM groups 
 Reduced unplanned pregnancies by increasing the uptake of effective 
methods of contraception. 
 Increased diagnosis and effective management of sexually transmitted 
infections 
 Increased uptake of HIV testing with particular emphasis on first time 
service users and repeat testing of those that remain at risk 
 Improved quality across all sexual health services in Leeds through 
clinical leadership

Description:

HEALTHCARE 
Leeds City Council (LCC) directorate of Adult Social Care have embarked on

management, information sharing and information security. As part of this 
development, the Council is seeking to procure a system for publishing new home

 The capability to securely hold data for multiple care packages for 
publishing to multiple prospective homecare providers, for background sharing 
with care record and monitoring systems, and for performance reporting. 
 Improved data management, data security and secure communication at every 
stage during the brokerage process. 
 The facility to automatically generate comprehensive management reports 
regarding the take up and delivery of homecare packages. This will include 
date/time stamping of key events as part of the process to broker care packages 
to providers.

Description:
The Leeds City Region Green Deal project aims to establish a long-term 
partnership with a leading Green Deal Provider/consortium in order to offer 
high quality and good value energy efficiency improvements to 
residents.  
The project will cover the whole of the Leeds City Region (and potentially 
parts of N Yorkshire and East Riding) with equal access, value for money and 
terms and conditions for all residents, regardless of location.  
The project will be available to any resident regardless of tenure or 
housing design, construction type, size and fuel type used for heating and hot 
water.  
The project will be open to all private sector households and the winning 
tender will be encouraged to design marketing approaches that the private 
sector will respond to. Many of the LCR housing authorities and housing 
associations have indicated that they are also interested in working with the 
winning tenderer to deliver social housing projects in specific 
estates. These are likely to be predominantly system built properties, 
solid walled Victorian properties and multi-storey blocks and properties with 
narrow cavities.   
Bidders will also be encouraged to consider opportunities within the non 
domestic market. 
The winning tenderer/consortia will have ultimate responsibility for turnkey 
project delivery. Upon appointment, they will be required to market and 
manage a LCR wide private sector Green Deal/ECO scheme. This will provide, 
as a minimum, the following three broad types of offer, to be delivered 
throughout the LCR area:  
A.       Delivery of a free HHCRO 
scheme, including free HHCRO fully GD accredited assessments and installation 
of free HHCRO measures; 
B.       Delivery of a full range of 
Green Deal measures, including Green Deal Assessments, within CSCO areas. This 
will aim to maximise the CSCO component to reduce the cost to households; 
and 
C.       Delivery of a full range of 
Green Deal measures, including Green Deal Assessments, to all households in LCR 
not eligible for HHCRO and CSCO. This will offer customers a choice of 
loans or customer contributions and will aim to maximise CERO funding;

ContractTitle: Leeds Directory Service
Description:
Background 
� 
With increasing demands on the local authority to provide for people with 
the highest levels of care needs, the �Keeping House� project was established 
in 2005 to create new ways to continue to address basic, but all-important, 
domestic needs of older people and disabled people.  
� 
One of Keeping House�s primary functions was to develop and maintain a list 
of domestic services, which could assist Leeds� strategic objective to help 
older people and disabled people to live independently in their own homes for 
as long as they wish to do so. 
� 
Alongside the Directory, a quality assurance function for domestic providers 
was established. This gave assurance that providers of services in the home or 
garden who were listed in the Directory met specific quality assurance criteria 
to allow them to become �Green Tick� providers. 
� 
Since April 2009, the Keeping House Directory and the Quality Assurance 
function have been contracted out from the local authority to an external 
provider that has developed and run the service. 
� 
In 2010 the directory was rebranded as the �Leeds Directory� and its remit 
expanded to list all services that enabled people to remain independent in 
their own home. The target audience for the directory was also expanded to 
include people with a learning disability and a mental health problem, in-line 
with the personalisation agenda. 
� 
Since its inception the Directory has continued to expand and now lists over 
1,700 organisations and services. 6,721 people accessed the Directory in the 
last month (January 2013 stats) which is an increase of 242 compared to last 
January. 
� 
Leeds Directory provides information on services, but does not allow for 
online purchasing. Alongside the continuing growth of the Leeds Directory, a 
separate website has been developed (Connect to Support Leeds) to allow 
customers to purchase care and support services on line. This is being provided 
as part of a regional project with all the Yorkshire and Humber local 
authorities by an organisation called Shop4Support. 
� 
It is intended that the increasing popularity of the Directory as a method 
for providers advertising services and customers accessing information can be 
harnessed and coupled with the Connect to Support functionality to allow people 
to research and purchase services online. Leeds Directory will continue to 
provide the directory of services available and the quality assurance function, 
while customers will be able to purchase goods and services from the Connect to 
Support site. To allow this to happen, close links will need to be forged and 
maintained between the provider of the Leeds Directory and the provider of the 
Connect to Support site (Shop4Support). 
� 
� 
Scope of the service to be provided 
� 
The aim of the Leeds Directory service is: 
� 
a). To provide, maintain and further develop the Leeds Directory, an online 
Directory of services which support people to remain independent (www.leedsdirectory.org)  
b). To run a Leeds Directory helpline to answer customer queries and give 
customers information on services where they do not have internet access 
c). To provide the Quality Assurance function for services listed in the 
Leeds Directory that deliver services in the home or garden  
� 
� 
d). To ensure links are formed and maintained with the �Connect to Support� 
website which provides customers with the ability to purchase services from 
providers listed on-line 
�

� 
i)������������ 
� Provision of information which enables individuals to choose� the 
support they need to max the opportunity for independent living 
ii)������������ 
Contribute to informing as many target client groups in Leeds about services 
and opportunities in a local, accessible, and comprehensive way 
iii)����������� 
Enable health and social care professionals to access information which 
supports them to promote services to individuals  
iv)���������� Enable 
service providers to effectively promote themselves to citizens in Leeds  
v)����������� 
Awareness and reputation of the directory service increases amongst all target 
stakeholders  
�

helpline
